title: letters to the editor november 15 2019
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I concur wholeheartedly with Rev Mackenzie’s concerns, the Argyllshire Advertiser, November , about the dangers surrounding the Cairnbaan road junction with the A.I had to make representations to the council about road signs being covered by vegetation last year.I travel through this junction most days of the week, often several times per day. Those of us familiar with it know full well to treat it with respect and to be particularly careful when coming away from Cairnbaan towards Lochgilphead.Like Rev Mackenzie, I am aware of a number of accidents there over the last  months. I would estimate at least five,not more. This is a hugely disproportionate amount compared with other junctions on this road. That fact alone should ring alarm bells with the roads authority.This, however, is not the be-all-and-end-all. I have personally witnessed more near misses at the junction than I would care to mention. The problem comes particularly, but not exclusively, during the height of the tourist season with drivers who are not familiar with the area.Rev Mackenzie quite rightly points out there is a deceptive vista that appears to make the road look like a long straight one and despite the presence of warning signs, for some reason, these are ignored.I thought it rather a trite response from Argyll and Bute Council, which is effectively saying the junction meets all legal requirements sign wise and motorists need to be more aware. It is effectively shrugging its shoulders about the reality of the situation and refusing to take the constant presence of risk seriously.It really does need someone to come up with a genuine solution that will eliminate these risks as far as humanly possible and hopefully curtail the number of incidents that will inevitably occur in futurenothing positive is done.Peter J Garrett, Ardrishaig.Sir,We are now into gloomier weather conditions and on occasions a low sun casts long shadows on our roads.I have advice for cyclists who venture on to the highways wearing black hats, black jackets, black trousers, black shoes, carrying black bags and riding their black bikes.Wear clothes that enhance your visibility, please.Earlier this year, in such conditions, I passed such a cyclist on my way into Oban. He was just starting on the incline out of Kilmore so the black tarmac was his background.It was his moving right foot on the pedal I noticed. At first I thought it was a dog on the road until my headlights picked him up.Tom Cullen, Dunskeig, Ardfern.We would like to invite readers to nominate a deserving carer for a chance of going on a free holiday, while the person they care for comes on a free break with us, Revitalise, through our new Grace Award for Caring.Carers save the economy £ billion per year, which is more than the NHS budget. The Grace Award for Caring was named not only because it takes grace to care for someone, but because it takes grace to accept care from someone.To nominate a carer visit www.revitalise.org.uk graceawards or call  .Abby Kessock-Philip, Revitalise.Sir,From October to December, deer are more likely to be on the road as they move down to lower ground to find food and shelter.The majority of collisions take place in early evening through to midnight, with another peak from am to am.Particularly in these peak times, we advise motorists to slow down and watch for deer crossing roads.Deer can suddenly appear before you have time to brake. If you do hit a deer, report it to the police, evenyou are uninjured and your car is not damaged, as the deer may be fatally injured and suffering.Jamie Hammond, SNH management officer.

title: a light in the darkness
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAlong with the popular winter fayre across the road at the parish church hall, Lochgilphead#s St Margaret#s Catholic Church welcomed people to light a candle to remember loved ones gone.On Saturday November , people made their way between the two buildings. In contrast to the noise and bustle of the fundraising fayre, the church was a haven of peace.Father Ronald Campbell said: #This week is Catholic Education week, when the church tries to promote its beliefs and practices to as wide an audience as possible.#The custom of lighting candles is a signicant convention in Catholic and Orthodox churches, communities and families, originating from Old Testament times where an oil lamp was lit to sustain a perpetual flame.#It was lovely to see many non-Catholics visit St Margaret#s and light candles for their personal intentions.#Small candles are known as votive or vigil candles and are used for the intention of prayers, for a specic issue or perhaps an inidual.They are used to remember the deceased, especially loved ones, and of those held dear, though candles tend to be lit for the Holy Souls throughout November.Prayers are usually spoken over one candle at a time. In keeping these candles burning for extended periods, the inidual prayer is believed to be prolonged and amplied along with the intentions of other believers’ prayers.In doing this, a collective spirit of prayer for the entire church is established which is encouraging, enriching and empowering.

Tarbert firm RDS Forestry kindly agreed to replace the tree with a more spruce alternative.The new tree, described by Andrew Dixon of RDS as #a beauty#, arrived on the back of a contractor#s lorry on the morning of Wednesday December , and the old one was taken away, tinsel flying in the wind as it left.Then Argyll and Bute Council took over.A council lorry later arrived on the scene beside the beautul bushy festive specimen.And council workers promptly started to chop up the replacement tree and throw it on the back of their lorry.Andrew Dixon explained in a Facebook post on Wednesday: #We liaised with the council who kindly said they would happily erect [a new tree]we delivered.#All agreed and we would drop new tree and remove the old one so that there was no hassle while the lorry was there.#Anyway, new tree was delivered this morning and the rest is history. title: drivers-face-disruption-a72-galashiels-next-week
story: DRIVERS on the A at Galashiels will face major disruption from next week.At am on Monday, work will begin in Island Street to upgrade the telecoms network, power connection and repair manhole covers.And it will run until Thursday, December .The works will see temporary three-way traffic lights installed at the Island Street Hall Street junction.They will operate   throughout the roadworks and will be manned from am to pm each day.But this means the permanent traffic lights at the Bridge Place High Street Island Street junction to be switched off during the works.In its place will be a give-way system, with traffic from Bridge Place and Island Street having priority over High Street road users.Signage will be in place to advise road users of the temporary arrangements.The pedestrian crossing will not be available at the junction during the works.Buses will operate as normal, but the Peebles-bound bus stop on Island Street will be moved to the other side of the Hall Street junction.Councillor Gordon Edgar, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoIf carried out as three separate projects, these works would have taken a month in total but have been co-ordinated by the council and the utility firms to ensure the disruption is minimised.ldquoWe have made the decision to switch off the permanent lights at the Bridge Place High Street Island Street junction as leaving them on would have created signicantly longer delays for road users.ldquoWe would advise motorists to give themselves plenty of time during the works and we thank them in advance for their co-operation.

title: bike-friendly-buses-rolled-peebles-pilot-success
story: BIKING in the Borders is set for a major boost as a local bus company rolls out its cycle friendly vehicles.A trial at the start of this year saw three new double-deckers equipped with bike racks start operating between Edinburgh and Peebles.The Borders Buses vehicles also had comfy leather seats, wireless charging and free WiFi.Bikers from all over have used the service throughout the summer.And the pilot was so popular a further  new vehicles have been equipped with the same facilities - operating on the X route along the A, the X Galashiels-to-Edinburgh-via Peebles route, and the  coastal service from Berwick to Edinburgh.There are currently  of the new vehicles now in operation, with another  to be added to the network by the end of next February.And another double-decker has also been refitted with a bike rack.Colin Craig, managing director at Borders Buses parent company West Coast Motors, told us: ldquoThe areas we cover include some of the most popular destinations in the UK for cyclists and our trials on our X Galashiels-Peebles-Edinburgh route have proved conclusively pedal power and horsepower do work together.ldquoWe very much see bus as part of the active travel solution and this initiative introduces a fantastic new dimension to sustainable greener travel."We recognise cyclists are prepared to ditch their cars for our bike-and-bus combination, all of which is great news in terms of reducing traffic congestion and vehicle emissions, enhancing the environment and encouraging people to jump on a bike and get active.Designed to make bus a more attractive greener transport option, the successful bike bus trial focused on encouraging less car journeys, reducing congestion on key routes and creating a sustainable travel solution for first and last mile travel connections.The new single deck Enviro  MMC vehicles, which have been custom built by Falkirk bus builder Alexander Dennis Limited, are equipped with two bike racks each as well as the same features as the trial vehicles.Transport cabinet secretary Michael Matheson has welcomed the pound. million investment by Borders Buses.He said: ldquoThis is a welcome investment from Borders Buses and the West Coast Motors Group, supporting our ambition to build an active nation having recognised and responded to customer demand.ldquoThis innovative step will encourage joined up and sustainable everyday journeys using both bikes and buses ndash improving our air quality and reducing congestion by creating new reasons to leave the car at home.Service X currently has  bike-friendly vehicles in operation with four bike-friendly double deckers operating on the X service.Borders Buses will add another six bike-friendly vehicles to the Peebles route in February.Charlie Miller, from vehicle manufacturers Alexander Dennis Limited, added: ldquoColin and his team at Borders Buses have a reputation for setting the pace."This project is another example of the vision and foresight that has established them at the forefront of the passenger transport sector."Others will recognise that working in tandem, to use an appropriate expression, bikes and buses can make a signicant contribution to a greener, cleaner environment and boost the tourism industry, particularly in rural communities."Pictures- from left Colin Craig, Michael Matheson and Charlie MillerRHU - the bike bus being enjoyed by cyclistsRHU - the bike racksRHU and  - Service  - Scotlands first bike friendly bus route

story: A HAWICK man will stand trial at Jedburgh Sherf Court charged with causing a disturbance at Borders General Hospital and assaulting police officers.Alexander Deans of Earl Street, pleaded not guilty to shouting and swearing, singing loudly and spitting on the floor of the toilet area at the hospital on September  as well as inside a police vehicle.He is also accused of making threatening, offensive and homophobic comments.The -year-old is also accused of spitting at a female police officer at the hospital and seizing a male constable by the neck.Deans pleaded not guilty to a fourth charge of being drunk and incapable in Backdamgate, Hawick, earlier that day and being incapable of looking after himself.A trial date has been fixed for November .

title: peebles-high-school-remain-closed-christmas
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has announced that Peebles High School will remain closed up to the Christmas break.Due to the signicant damage caused to the old gym, art classrooms and surrounding rooms, as well as other areas of the school, the decision has been made to keep the school closed until after the Christmas holidays.Students and parents will be informed in the coming days of where classes will be relocated, alongside opportunities for online learning.SBC will utilise the Groupcall service to communicate with parents and carers.Students with complex needs will be able to attend classes at the Galashiels Complex Needs Centre.Chief Executive of SBC, Tracey Logan said: ldquoThis fire has resulted in some serious damage to the school and it just wouldnrsquot be safe or practical to open it without taking time to properly assess the damage and plan the recovery."To minimise disruption wersquove taken a swt decision to close it right through to the Christmas break."Wersquore making sure we have plans in place to ensure pupils have the best learning experience possible and are supported appropriately for the remaining  school days left before the holidays."There will be a particular focus on helping pupils who are preparing to sit prelim exams.A spokesperson for SBC added: "We are working on arrangements for pupils and staff to get back their belongings that were left in the school when it was evacuated on Thursday."We canrsquot do this until the emergency services give us full access to the school but wersquoll communicate details as soon as possible."The old gym was also set out to be a polling station for the upcoming general election on December . title: stampede-expected-elephant-sessions-festive-gig-galashiels
story: EXPECT a stampede later this month as Elephant Sessions take to the MacArts stage in Galashiels.The award-winning band have a huge following all over their native Scotland.And their exciting festivals with audiences crowd surfing their way through the summer and marquee floors breaking under the weight of bouncing fans.The Mercury nominated Alt-J, along with BBC Radio , have found themselves converted to the bandrsquos unique brand of music.Charting in the French download charts and selling bucket loads across Europe, All We Have Is Now firmly established this band as completely unique.Their latest album, What Makes You, builds on this success and sees the front line of mandolin and fiddle pushing their limits further, matching the percussive rhythm of drums, bass and guitar, whilst fusing with electronic dance beats.Mandolin player Alasdair Taylor told us: "What Makes You is a musical progression of the journey the band have been on since the last album."We feel like our sound has matured and wersquore playing and writing the music that we really want to be playing."Writing and performing the music from this new album has been so much fun so far and we title: conquering-skies---tale-border-connections
story: Chairman of the Cricket Society of Scotland and of the Gala Water History and Heritage Association, local historian Fraser Simm, tells the story of flying machines and a link to a famous cricketer who came to the Borders  years ago.THE cross currents of history often lap up on unusual shores.The th anniversary of the first flight from Britain to Australia has links with the Borders and the south of Scotland.At the end of the First World War in  there was a surfeit of planes and pilots with time on their hands and this was followed by a flurry of long distance flights which echoed the days of the Portuguese sailors as they gradually made their way round Africa in the th century.In July  the milestone of the first crossing of the Atlantic Ocean by John Alcock and Arthur Brown was achieved. The success of this flight was the impetus for pioneer flights from London to Australia and Cape Town and it is the former that is my subject.In May  the Australian government offered a prize of poundA, for the first Australians in a British aircraft to fly from Great Britain to Australia. In November  six entries started the race. Only two of these reached their final destination the other four crashed in Surbiton, Corfu, Crete and Bali .Of the two flights that succeeded, the clear winners were Ross and Keith Smith they piloted a Vickers Vimy aeroplane and were joined by two mechanics, Wally Shiers and Jim Bennett. Their flight left Hounslow on November ,  and after  days and , miles they arrived at Darwin on December  stops included Lyon, Rome, Cairo, Damascus, Basra, Karachi, Delhi, Calcutta, Rangoon, Singora, Singapore, Batavia and Surabaya. This compares with just under four weeks that it took my grandparents to sail to Perth when they emigrated from Edinburgh to seek a new le in Australia in  with help from the Assisted Passage Scheme.Pilot Ross Smith had flown for T E Lawrence during the First World War and in  he flew the first pioneering flight from Cairo to Calcutta which must have helped the record breaking journey the following year. The Smith brothers received knighthoods and the four members of the crew shared the prize of poundA,. The runners up, who left London on January ,  took  days to reach Darwin, arriving in August . These two flights compare with the recent ldquoworldrsquos longest flight -  hour non-stop from New York to Sydney.The two Smith brothers received a congratulatory telegram from the headmaster of small Scottish school,ldquoWell done Ross and Keith Warriston proud of you Mr F W Gardner headmaster.F Gardner was the headmaster of Warriston School in Moffat where the Smith brothers ndash and their sibling Colin ndash had spent the final two years of their education.Ross and Keith Smith both had the middle name of their mother ldquoMacpherson she was the daughter of an immigrant family from Scotland. Their father had been born in Moffat and emigrated to Western Australia, and in sending their three sons to Moffat to complete their education they were clearly strengthening their bonds with ldquothe old country.The Smith brothers were therefore grounded in Scotland.A well-known fact in the world of cricket is that the famous Australian all-rounder Keith Millerwas named after the two Smith brothers his parents named him Keith Ross Miller. It is not known whether Keith Miller realised that the Smith brothers had Scottish ancestry, but as he played wartime cricket matches in Scotland and visited again in  it is nice to speculate. Millerrsquos wartime service as a mosquito pilot adds a certain symmetry to the achievements of his distinguished namesakes.When he was in Scotland in  playing for the RAAF, Miller lodged with the McVey family in Clovenfords and when he ed with ldquoThe Invincibles in  he planted a tree in Selkirk and called in on the family to renew his acquaintance.In  I paid a visit to Selkirk to seeI could see the tree planted by Miller but was told it had been destroyed in a storm - this story came full circle when I recently spoke to Hazel McLean who used to live in Clovenfords and had met Keith Miller in  when he called on the McVeys.She recalled being taken by her parents to their friendsrsquo house nearby and the excitement in getting his autograph. On hearing this, I took a short journey to Clovenfords and was delighted to locate ldquothe white house just before the bend which is where the McVeys apparently resided.Like many such encounters, only a smattering of memories remain but a little stardust goes a long, long way.

title: jane-fiona-become-queens-nurses
story: A#CARE home nurse and a learning disability nurse have both been awarded#the prestigious title of Queenrsquos Nurse.##Jane Douglas, Chief Executive at Queenrsquos House in Kelso, and Fiona Mason, a senior charge nurse within the Scottish Borders Learning Disability Service, were selected earlier this year to take part in a nine-month development programme run by the Queenrsquos Nursing Institute Scotland.##Both were nominated#by their employers for providing high quality, compassionate care to people in their communities.#After completing the programme successfully,#they were awarded the historic Queenrsquos Nurse title along with  other community nurses at a ceremony in Edinburgh on Thursday.###Jane has been with Queenrsquos House for around three years and was appointed Chief Executive in April.The charity, which employs approximately  staff, has two care homes - Queens House and Murray House.Jane said: ldquoI have worked in care home nursing for many years across a range of roles before I was lucky enough to get my current job."I love where I am now - I am where I am meant to be.ldquoMy aim is that people experience le in a care home positively, that they have a voice and they are able to be autonomous as much as they can be. By doing this and listening hard to what people prefer, I hope we are able to achieve wellbeing.ldquoItrsquos an honour and a privilege to receive the Queenrsquos Nurse title. I am passionate about promoting the role of the nurse in care homes, an important role which requires skills and knowledge in the field of older people and people living with dementia. I hope now to be able to further raise the profile of nurses in care homes.Fiona, who is based in Earlston, works within a multidisciplinary team across health and social care.She said: ldquoWorking as a community learning disability nurse I am in a very privileged position to be welcomed into peoplersquos homes to work alongside iniduals, their families and carers.ldquoTo have people share parts of their le story with me is something I never take for granted. A large part of my role is assessing, monitoring, managing and treating physical and mental health. I work together with people with learning disabilities to help them navigate the system, so they are able to receive the expert care they need.ldquoHaving the Queenrsquos Nurse title will help to raise the profile of learning disability nursing, which is very important to me. Itrsquos been an honour to have been given the opportunity to be part of an inspirational, innovative and forward-thinking group of nurses who can problem solve and lead change to improve the quality of services within our ious areas of expertise.Fiona was congratulated by the director of nursing, midwery and acute services at NHS Borders, Nicky Berry.She said: ldquoWe are delighted that Fiona has been selected as a Queenrsquos Nurse."The sht towards providing care closer to peoplersquos homes offers exciting opportunities for the further development of community nursing.ldquoFionarsquos work within the Scottish Borders is vital and we look forward to there being more Queenrsquos nurses across NHS Borders.Other community nurses in the group include#a Macmillan nurse, a dementia specialist nurse and a nurse working in homelessness services, as well as district nurses, health visitors, school nurses and practice nurses.###They#were all presented with their title by author Christie Watson at the ceremony at#Edinburghrsquos Waldorf Astoria hotel.###In  the Queenrsquos Nursing Institute Scotland is celebrating its th anniversary. The original Queenrsquos Nurses provided#care and health#education#to people in their own#homes and#became well respected figures within their community.###Following#the introduction of a national certicate for district#nursing, QNIS ceased training, awarding the#QN#title for the final time in .###However, the decision was made to reintroduce Queenrsquos Nurses to Scotland in ,#with# community nurses chosen to take part in a development programme which would see them become the first modern Queenrsquos Nurses.###The process involves#employers#nominating a#community-based#nurse#who will#go forward for interview following a successful#written#application.####The#programme#consists of a week-long residential workshop followed by two further workshops and coaching sessions in between.#Each#nurse selects#an issue for#development#which will have a signicant impact on those they care for, so that the learning during the nine months is applied in practice.####Clare Cable, QNIS Chief#Executive#and Nurse Director,#told us:#ldquoThree years on from reintroducing the Queenrsquos Nurse title to Scotland, we now have #Queenrsquos Nurses working in communities across the country.##ldquoThey are extraordinary role models for nursing in the community and show the enormous contribution which nurses make to the health of Scotlandrsquos people.##ldquoThis yearrsquos Queenrsquos Nurses demonstrate the ersity of community nursing roles, with the welcome addition of Queenrsquos Nurses working in learning disabilities, and another working in sexual health for the first time.###ldquoThey are all expert community nurses - change makers across the country.#######

title: folksy-festive-fun-comes-st-boswells
story: A WONDERFUL show filled with music, wonder, puppets and silliness is heading to St Boswells.Following their sell-out show last Christmas, the Folksy Theatre Company makes a welcometo the village hall.This year, the talented company is coming with their new musical, The Elves and the Shoemaker, a captivating story about generosity, kindness and a couple of mischievous elves.The Elves and the Shoemaker tells the story of a poor cobbler and his we who have no money and just enough leather to make one last pair of shoes.Then, good fortune suddenly smiles upon them.While the shoemaker sleeps, someone fashions the most perfect pair of shoes imaginable - and a delighted customer pays twice the asking price!Who could have done such marvellous work  And will the magic continue Filled with Folksyrsquos touch of wonderful live music, puppetry, multimedia and downright silliness, this wonderful musical will have the whole family entertained.Youth arts mentor with promoters Live Borders, Aylfe Rose said: "Events like this in village halls help to strengthen the community by bringing people together around a positive, happy occasion."This fun-filled show will bring laughter and smiles to all the family and get everyone into the spirit of Christmas.The Elves and the Shoemaker starts at pm in St Boswells Village Hall on Friday, December .Tickets, priced at pound for adults and pound for children and concessions, are available on the door and from www.liveborders.org.uk.

title: christmas-toy-town-marches-galashiels
story: THE festive fun is set to continue after Christmas in Galashiels.Childrens performers Funbox are bringing their magical new seasonal show, Christmas in Toy Town, to the Volunteer Hall on Sunday, December .This brand-new spectacular features Anya, Kevin, Gary and Bonzo the Dog.With singalongs including, Bunny Fou Fou, The Grand Old Duke Of York and festive favourite, Jingle Bells, the show is perfect for staying in the festive spirit in the days after Santas headed back at the North Pole.Therersquos trouble in Toy Town because someonersquos arrived who is up to snow good.The mischievous Gnorbert the Gnome is about, creating mayhem and pinching everyonersquos favourite things.Santa has asked the gang to look after his most precious toy, so itrsquos up to them to make sure Gnorbert doesnrsquot get his hands on it.Plus, there are keys to discover, games to play, and songs to sing.Everyone is invited to dress up as - or bring along - their favourite toy.Or, even don your Santa hat and have a sing-a-long.Olly Robertson from promoters Live Borders said: "Following the massive success of the Fun Box shows in Hawick and Galashiels over the summer, we are delighted to have them back."This is just one event in a packed programme of festive fun events from Live Borders this year.Christmas in Toy Town is on Sunday, December  at Galashiels Volunteer Hall, starting at pm.Tickets, priced at pound or pound for a family ticket, are available on the door and from www.liveborders.org.uk

title: community-centre-study-zone-offer-peebles-high-pupils
story: PEEBLES High pupils living around the West Linton area are being offered a local community centre for studying.An announcement on the schooling of the  pupils while their fire-ravaged school remains closed is expected today.But staff at the Newlands Community Centre are flinging open the doors for up to  of the students to use for as a study space.Joe Fernand from Newlands told us: "Since the terrible fire at Peebles High School and its closure until further notice the Newlands Centre is opening its doors to Peebles High School students offering them a safe, warm and equipped study zone with smart board."We can accommodate up to  pupils."Newlands Volunteers will coordinate adult supervision of the study zone plus assist students getting online to access student resources and where possible coordinate volunteer tutors."Newlands is also appealing for any volunteers to help at the makesht study zone.For further information contact Mr Fernand at joef@newlandscdt.org.uk or telephone .

title: locals-asked-stay-away-peebles-high
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council, alongside Police Scotland and the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service are appealing for the community to keep away from the site of last weeks fire as investigations continue and there is still a safety risk.John McKenzie, Police Scotland Chief Superintendent, said: "We are aware of youths who have entered the building, placing themselves at risk."This is a hazardous and unsafe environment for anyone to be in. We would ask parents and carers to assist us talk to your child about the potential dangers and the consequences as this could make a dference to their safety."We will take action against anyone found within the site.ldquoWe are continuing to carry out investigations into the fire, along with Scottish Fire and Rescue Service."SFRS Area Commander, Steve Gourlay added: "Not only is this site a dangerous environment for anyone to be in at this time, it also remains a live incident ground with SFRS resources and our partners in attendance.ldquoWe would therefore urge everyone to stay away from the site for their own safety and to allow us and our partners to carry out our investigations and ensure the area is made as safe as possible.ldquoWe will work with our partners to ensure as many people as possible are aware of the risks, however the community can play its part by helping to spread the message, particularlythey think someone may be thinking of entering the site.From Tuesday, December  until Friday, December , all students from Peebles High are being asked to stay at homeand use the Show My Homework App, Scholar and Glow.All preliminary exams have also been postponed.SBC Chief Executive, Tracey Logan, said: ldquoIt is extremely dangerous for anyone to come close to, or try and enter, any part of the school. I cannot stress enough how important it is to remain well clear of the school site at this time.ldquoI understand that people are keen to get back their belongings that may have been left behind during the evacuation. I can assure everyone that we are working on arrangements.ldquoWe will communicate details on this as soon as possible via Groupcall, on our website and social media channels."SBC is making arrangements for students for the coming weeks, including the availability of temporary learning sites, transport and catering.Were you or your child children impacted by the fire  Get in touch. Email isabelle.truscott@newsquest with the subject: PHS Fire

title: christmas-kicks-off-gala-sparkling-switch-on
story: THERE was plenty of festive fun for all the family in Galashiels on Saturday.Locals and visitors descended on the town centre for the Christmas lights switch-on.They had the chance to browse the many stalls which were set up in Bank Street as well as enjoy some pop hits from Little Mix tribute band, Little Chix.And members of Galashiels Christmas Lights Committee were delighted that all their hard work paid idends.Anne Carrie from the group told us: "It was absolutely amazing for the town of Galashiels."The people and the businesses have supported us  per cent."We have been fundraising for months and people have volunteered their time. We could not have done it without them."We have also had the expertise of fantastic professionals to help us to put the lights up."We are overwhelmed with the kindness of people who helped make this event happen."The day was a real family affair with activities on offer for all ages.As well as the many stalls, there was also a visit from the Velvet Hall alpacas and musical entertainment from the Town Band, Ex-Service Pipe Band and Langlee Choir.And at pm the lights were switched on in front of a large crowd in Bank Street Gardens by the Little Chix.Anne added: "The ethos of the group was to create a free event for families and also revitalise and increase footfall in Galashiels town centre."Were hoping that this is the start of something that takes off year after year and just grows bigger and bigger."We are very pleased with the market stalls. We took a long time to try and source stalls."Their offering has been fantastic and I think the traders have enjoyed the day. We are now going to get feedback to see how we can improve next year."We would also like to thank Scottish Borders Council. They have supported us in terms of Localities Bid Funding, their expertise in regards to the lighting and generally just a real willingness to be part of it and help the town enjoy this day."

title: euan-praised-work-community
story: COUNCILLOR Euan Jardine has been highly commended for his work in the community at this years Councillor Awards.Councillor Jardine, who has been a councillor since , was shortlisted as a finalist in the rural community champion category at the second-annual Councillor Awards held in Edinburgh last week.He was nominated alongside councillor Shona Haslam , who was put forward for leader of the year.This category was won by councillor John Alexanderat the ceremony on Thursday, November .Although the award for rural community champion was won by councillor Elena Whitham , councillor Jardine was highly commended by LGiU Chief Executive, Jonathan Carr-West, for his work in the community.Particularly, his engagement with local groups and activities, including the Mens Shed and the Gala Waterways Group.Mr Carr-West added: "Tonight, we are incredibly proud to unveil this yearrsquos Councillor Award winners, a group of iniduals who truly showcase the best of local government."Their work to make our communities safer, stronger and healthier so often goes unrecognised. That is why it is important that we honour them this evening."I would like to extend my most sincere congratulations to Councillor Jardine and thank him for his commitment to local government. We look forward to hearing more about his continued accomplishments in the future."The Councillor Awards are the only awards to recognise the work done by councillors across Scotland.

title: climate-change-hot-topic-first-hustings-event
story: TRANSPORT and fossil fuel dominated the Scottish Bordersrsquo first ever lsquogreen hustingsrsquo.All four candidates standing in the Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk constituency, which covers all of the Scottish Borders except Tweeddale, appeared before an audience in Melrose on Wednesday to answer questions about climate change and sustainability.Organised by Greener Melrose, a coalition of ious environmental groups in the Borders, the hustings was held at Marmions Place, on Buccleuch Street in Melrose.The , headed by Greener Melrosersquos Donald McPhillimy, included John Lamont , Calum Kerr , Jenny Marrand Ian Davidson .There was standing room only in the small bar, and Mr Phillimy got the evening underway by telling the audience: ldquoI think this demonstrates the fact that the climate emergency has finally climbed up the political agenda, and it is something that a lot of people are concerned about and interested in.ldquoThis is the first green hustings, as far as Irsquom aware, certainly in this part of the world, so I think itrsquos really signicant that we are meeting here tonight to talk about predominantly green issues.The  was asked pre-selected questions by members of the audience, which ranged in topic from Scotlandrsquos reliance on oil, the burning of heather on grouse moors in the Borders, and the quality of public transport in the region.On the latter topic, an audience member expressed their dismay to the  that the Borders Railway runs on diesel, while another asked how they would encourage people to use public transport more often.Responding, Labourrsquos Ian Davidson said: ldquoBus usage in Scotland in the last ten years has fallen by over ten percent. Thatrsquos because therersquos been a lack of strategic vision. You cannot expect public transport, such as buses, to pay for itself,itrsquos going to be a consistent service.ldquoIn Glasgow, we realised that keeping buses on during the night was vital because although they wouldnrsquot be used often, when people did use them it would be urgent.ldquoNow, Scottish Borders Council, in my view, does not adequately fund public transport."They say, and I think theyrsquore absolutely right, that theyrsquore inadequately funded by the Scottish Government.ldquoThe Scottish Government say: lsquoit was a bad boy who done it and he ran away because Westminster didnrsquot give us enough moneyrsquo. Now, thatrsquos an example of where there needs to be a degree of strategic thinking.ldquoOn the question of the train being driven by oil, that, as I understand it, was because it was going to be far too expensive to electry it.ldquoThey could only get diesel-driven stock, so it was that or nothing. Now thatrsquos not acceptable. Itrsquos also not acceptable, in my view, that the rails the Borders line runs on were actually made in China.ldquoThat didnrsquot create pollution here in Scotland, but it did across the world and the jobs werenrsquot created here they were created in China.Conservative candidate John Lamont said: ldquoSome parts of the Borders are very well connected but a lot are not,you speak to residents in Newcastleton or Paxton, they do not have a regular bus service to allow them to get around, so itrsquos wrong to say that buses and public transport are accessible.ldquoWersquore very lucky to have Borders Buses here, I have their exceptionally good app, I donrsquot knowmany of you use it but itrsquos a very simple way to get around and very easily find out where your bus is.ldquoI do use it, because itrsquos a good way to get around and itrsquos better for the environment.ldquoBut you canrsquot say that just because I can use it to get from Berwick Station to my house in Coldstream, that other people have access to public transport services, you canrsquot, because thatrsquos simply not true.On buses, Liberal Democrat candidate Jenny Marr said: ldquoBorders Buses is great, and the routes that have started this week with space for the bikes I think as really important.ldquoTo follow on from what John was saying, at Eyemouth College, they have a high rate of dropout In January and February because of how few buses there are and how dficult it is in the winter.ldquoI think we need to look at the successes in some parts of the region and then try and apply that to other places.ldquoI think with Newcastleton, one of the guys from the Campaign for Borders Rail was telling me thata kid wants to get out of the village on a Saturday they will struggle to get back after one or two in the afternoon, and I think we need to make sure that our public transport infrastructure is not a barrier to progress and not a barrier to children and younger people having the le they deserve to have.Finally, SNP candidate Calum Kerr added: ldquoIn relation to the points made on the railway, obviously there is a move around electrication and talk about hydrogen as well, the Scottish Government has set the target that the railways will be net-zero by , as it stands today.ldquoIn terms of public transport and buses, certainly when I met with bus companies previously, therersquos only two bus routes in the Borders which makes a profit, the X and the X.ldquoPeople just donrsquot use it, so it becomes self perpetuating, because then routes get cut, so people have to use their cars, soa green new deal means fundamentally resetting aspects of the economy, and included in that needs to be transport, then you have to invest:you build it they will come.ldquoYou canrsquot just hope people will start using it, and then yoursquoll find a way to make the routes work, it does require signicant investment.ldquoThere is a pound.m green bus fund, so itrsquos about adding green buses continually. There is a lot of work going on, but I think we can do more.The next general elections hustings are set to take place on Monday.At .am, BBC Scotland will host a hustings at Heart of Hawick, while in the evening a second hustings, organised by Selkirk Community Council, will take place at Victoria Halls, Selkirk, at pm.

title: musical-instruments-ready-collect-peebles-high
story: MUSICAL instruments left behind after last weeks fire are now ready to collect.All instruments have been collected from Peebles High School after the fire which has forced the High School to close until after Christmas.The instruments have been transported to Priorsford Primary School and will be available until pm today .Scottish Borders Council are making arrangements for further opportunities to collect belongings and instruments tomorrow , details of which will be released in due course.For all updates on the fire, visithttps:www.scotborders.gov.uk PHSfireHave you been impacted by the fire  Get in touch. title: gala-community-groups-give-wildlife-helping-hand-winter
story: GALA Waterways Group and the Mens Shed have joined forces to provide food for wildle this winter.The collaboration between the two community groups will see twelve bird boxes placed around the town over the coming weeks.Mens Shed member, Neil McDougall, was responsible for making the bird boxes which were made from donated and recycled wood. He said: "I was delighted to help with this request when we were asked to do it."We try to do a project every year and last year we helped the wildle trust by making squirrels boxes so they could collect data."We used a lot of donated and recycled wood in this project so happy it is going to a great cause like this. The effort of making the boxes is nothing compared to the feeling that you know you have contributed to helping the wildle."The bird box campaign follows on from plans made by the Gala Waterways Group in , which were halted due to works on the railway.Alistair Lings, one of the members of GWG added: "The environment and the wildle are very important to our group. We work throughout the year to clean and maintain the river and areas surrounding it."Some bird boxes were installed beside the Gala Water in the late s by another group."Its great that thanks to working with the menrsquos shed we are able to get our project on-track again."The coming together of these groups was thanks to the work of councillor Euan Jardine, who has worked with both groups during his time with the Scottish Borders Council.Councillor Jardine said of the bird box initiative: "When the idea of bird boxes was first discussed it made perfect sense for both groups to collaborate on this."It is important for community groups to come together."I am really grateful for both groups working on this and ensuring the wildle in the area will be looked after this winter."The two volunteering groups offer their services to their communities, either by providing spaces for people to develop new skills, such as in carpentry or gardening, or by helping to make the green spaces around Galashiels clear and enjoyable for all.Mens Shed coordinator, Ross Hall said: "ldquoI love that these two groups have come together."We want to give back to the community and very happy to support and donate these boxes to the Gala Waterways Group."I would encourage volunteers to come along to both the menrsquos shed and the Gala Waterways when they have free time."As volunteering is really worthwhile and a great way to socialise with like minded people."The Gala Mens shed is open every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday am-pm and is situated below Langlee Community Centre.And Gala Waterways Group meets every first Saturday of the month from am-pm at ious locations. For more information, contact David Usher, davidusher@btinternet

title: home-schooling-peebles-pupils-new-class-arrangements-horizon
story: PLANS are being put in place for pupils from Peebles High to be taught at alternative locations in the town as well as Galashiels.The  students were due toto the classrooms todayfollowing the St Andrews long weekend.But due to the extent of fire damage at the secondary, it wont reopen until after Christmas.Support plans are being drawn up with particular attention being given to pupils who have forthcoming prelim exams.A spokesman for the local authority told us: "Work has been ongoing over the weekend and Monday to put in place plans to provide specialist support for pupils this week and ensure the council maximises the opportunities to continue learning and provide specic support for students preparing for prelim exams."This will continue on Tuesday and an update will be provided to pupils, parents and carers."We expect to be able to put in place face-to-face teaching for all year groups from next Monday."We are exploring all options for accommodating pupils in alternative locations, including within Peebles and Galashiels."Arrangements to provide specialist support to pupils this week through drop-in sessions and telephone support are being finalised."Pupils are being encouraged to use Show My Homework App, Scholar and Glow to work from home during the rest of this week.Council convenor David Parker, Convener has praised the work of the emergency services as well as the community.He told us: "This has been a devastating incident for Peebles High Schoolrsquos pupils and staff and the local community.ldquoWithout the magnicent efforts of firefighters, it could have been signicantly worse in terms of damage to the school estate.ldquoCrews worked tirelessly to contain the fire for almost  hours, with up to  firefighters on the scene, highlighting the extent of the fire.ldquoDuring and in the aftermath of this challenging incident, the community of Peebles has also stepped forward to support the emergency services and the school.ldquoDuring the overnight fire we saw local people providing food, soup and hot drinks to the crews, while a local church opened its doors to pupils and staff and a local supermarket provided them with food.ldquoWe have also seen offers of assistance from businesses, including a local hotel who has agreed to host Peebles Highrsquos senior dance this week.ldquoOn behalf of the council, I thank all who have provided generous support during this extremely dficult incident for Peebles community.

title: borders-fiscal-goes-quietly-27-years
story: THE legal fraternity in the Borders turned out in force on Friday to bid a fond farewell to retiring procurator fiscal Graham Fraser.Representatives of the ious Criminal Justice Partners including law firms, police and the Crown Office joined staff from the sherf courts at Jedburgh and Selkirk to mark the end of a distinguished career -  years of which were served in the Borders as well as a y period working in Edinburgh.Rory Bannerman, senior partner at Bannerman Burke, led the tributes at the ceremony.He told the gathering: "Graham was fairness personied."Sherfs, clerks and solicitors all found him easy to deal with and that made our jobs so much easier."His knowledge and hard work have been of an unparalleled nature whether it was a most serious of crimes or a speeding offence."Graham is a leading light in the local brass band scene and, whilst never a man to blow his own trumpet, gave thousands of hours to the Jedforest band and others up and down the land, mainly to help encourage others."A family man he retires to help wash the dishes and walk the dogs with a vigour only previously seen when tackling an errant witness in the pursuit of Jethart justice."He thoroughly deserves his well-earned retirement, and the Bar hopes that he does notto work again for his sake given the years of public service he has already given to keep the Borders safe and in order."Mr Fraser was presented with a voucher for the Edinburgh New Town Cookery School so that he and his we Alison can enrol in a French cuisine course.

title: lauder-post-office-raided-early-hours
story: POLICE are appealing for help to catch two thieves who raided Lauder Post Office in the early hours of this morning.The culprits were disturbed by the post master at the Market Street premises at around am.But they still managed to escape with a quantity of cash.Officers have carried out a search of the area and carried out door-to-door enquiries this morning.PC Liam Myers said: "It appears that the break-in may have caused quite some noise."We are keen to hear from anyone who may have seen or heard anything suspicious in the Lauder area in the early hours of this morning."Anyone with information is asked to call Police Scotland on , quoting  and December .

title: teaching-arrangements-made-peebles-students
story: STUDENTS from Peebles High School will be able to access face-to-face teaching from Monday, December .Scottish Borders Council have announced that classes will be open to S-S students in the extension building at Galashiels Academy.These classes will be conducted by Peebles staff.Plans for S-S students are being finalised.Catering and transport are also being decided in preparation for next week.SBC are also looking at alternative locations to meet the needs of all students.Further details will be confirmed later today.For all updates on the provision of teaching and support for PHS students, visit https:www.scotborders.gov.uk news article  peebles_high_school_fire_update

title: football-tutor-yellow-carded-general-teaching-council
story: A FORMER sports tutor at Borders College has been reprimanded after students were forced to retake assessments.Stephen McLeish was the course tutor for football at the Galashiels campus since it was created in .And many leading young players have passed through his courses on their way to full time contracts with clubs like Hibernian, Livingston and Dunfermline.But between  and  McLeish breached strict guidelines by allowing his students to undertake SQA assessments on publicly accessible websites.He also stored their completed assessments towards HNC Coaching and Developing Sport on insecure sites which were accessible to other students.The General Teaching Council for Scotlandthrew out a further charge of him providing excessive direction to students due to a lack of evidence.And the  also decided not to pursue allegations of failing to assess students work fairly and failing to provide feedback on grounds they fell within charges of competence rather than conduct.But they did uphold two charges of misconduct in relation to the use of the insecure website Edmodo.A spokesperson for the GTCS said: "The integrity of the SQA system relied upon the appropriate conduct of teachers in conducting the assessment process and required that teachers conduct themselves with the utmost integrity in their dealings with them."The conduct had been unfair to pupils as they had been required to retake assessments and called into question their integrity during the assessment process."The conduct fell short of the standards expected of a registered teacher."The GTCS Panel decided that a Reprimand should remain in place for one year.The spokesperson added: "The teacher had admitted the conduct and had reflected on it."The conduct was isolated and there was no history of misconduct."In view of the Panel, a reprimand was an appropriate sanction to mark the seriousness of the conduct in the circumstances."Mr McLeish hasnt worked at Borders College since .The College declined to comment on the outcome of the hearing.

title: damp-despair-galashiels-widower
story: A YEAR after reporting a roof leak to his housing association Gordon McLean is now suffering in his damp and mould-infested flat.And to rub salt into the wounds of the -year-old widower, the social landlord is about to bump up his rent and have even sent a threatening reminder for pound arrears.Mr McLean first reported problems with an external roof pipe at his Galashiels property almost a year ago on December .Further problems developed after a new bathroom suite was fitted at his Talisman Avenue home during the summer.And it was only when wallpaper began peeling off his walls that action was finally taken to stop the dampness.Despite being issued with a dehumidier the former gamekeepers property is still damp and mould can be found in several rooms.Mr Mclean told us: "I first noticed water leaking off the roof and an outside pipe and coming into the walls."The water had to be coming into the walls, but the workmen didnt think there was anything wrong."They did repairs to my taps inside but they wouldnt believe me that there was a problem with water getting into the walls."After the new bathroom was fitted the dampness smell became more noticeable, and within a few weeks my wallpaper began falling off."After I lost my we two years ago I took a real pride in my flat and decorated every room."I had the place beautul, but look at it now."Theres mould growing through the carpets, mould on the walls, the wallpaper has come off - how is someone meant to live in a house like this "Electrical testing on the property also showed that several sockets were dangerous due to the encroaching dampness.And Mr Mclean has also developed a bad cough over the past few months.But the biggest blow for him has been SBHAs decision to increase his rent and also send out a warning letter.He added: "While this was going on I went to a meeting with SBHA and they announced my rent would be going up from pound to almost pound per week - who would pay pound a week to live like this "I just received another letter from them to sayI dont pay pound rent arrears as well they will take court action."My home has been ruined by them not repairing a leak and this how they treat me."Scottish Borders Housing Association deny that dampness issues were reported by Mr Mclean before October.But they admit they were called to his Talisman Avenue flat last December, and also carried out repairs to taps earlier in the year.A spokeswoman told us: "In December  an inspection was carried out by SBHA with no further action at that time."Repairs relating to an immersion heater and also taps had been carried out in the property earlier in  and dampness issues were not raised on these occasions."The tenant contacted us on October  and a job line was raised including a specialist survey commissioned to investigate the cause of the problem, prior to instruction of appropriate works."Remedial works are currently on site following investigations regarding water ingress."The Selkirk-based housing association has also defended its planned rent increases.The spokeswoman added: "In November , we carried out a consultation on the proposed rent levels for the following year, giving all , tenants the opportunity to provide feedback, via a wide iety of consultation methods, including paper survey, community roadshows and telephone surveys."We advise tenants of these opportunities via their autumn newsletter, website and Facebook. SBHA has one of the lowest rents in the Borders and is committed to providing affordable homes."

title: peebles-students-offered-pastoral-curricular-support-week
story: STUDENTS from Peebles High School will be able to attend pastoral and curricular drop-in sessions for the remainder of the week to support them emotionally, help with UCAS applications and to help guide learning on certain subjects.Pastoral staff will be available from todayuntil Friday, December  at the council office, Rosetta Road, Peebles. On Wednesdaythe staff will be in the office from am to pm, on Thursday, am to pm and on Friday, am to pm.Staff will be on site to help with UCAS and Oxbridge applications as well as providing emotional support to those affected by the fire.As well as Peebles High staff, partners from Quarriers, Skills Development Scotland , and Educational Psychology and School Nurse Service will be in attendance to provide another layer of support to students.Students can join these sessions by calling   to book an appointment orthey are unable to be there in person, students can use a telephone consultation service available through the same number.For curricular support, staff will be on site at the Peebles Community Centreand Kingsland Primary School todayand tomorrowfrom .am to pm and on Friday, December  from .am to pm.Todays sessions will focus on S-S students, tomorrows will focus on S-S and Friday will be open to all students.Drop-in support from the Community Centre will cover English and RMPS Health and Le Skills All Sciences Business and Computing, and support from Kingsland Primary will cover Maths Social Subjects Modern Languages Technical Expressive Arts.Telephone booking for these sessions can be made from am everyday and phone call support is also available to students who cant attend the drop-in sessions.For subjects from the Community Centre, call   and for subjects based in Kingsland Primary, call  .To contact a subject teacher directly, students can email using Glow.For the latest updates on support and teaching, visit https:www.scotborders.gov.uk news article  peebles_high_school_fire_update

title: extra-seats-promised-borders-railway-next-week
story: RAIL bosses have promised to increase the number of seats on the Borders Railway, from next week.A further , will be added on the Tweedbank to Edinburgh line each day from next Sunday.Just seven services between Monday and Friday will run with two carriages, as opposed to the current .And as part of the improvements, the .am and .am trains from Tweedbank will now have six coaches, rather than three.The changes come as part of a new timetable introduced by ScotRail, which also includes opening a new station in Glasgow.David Simpson, the companys operations director, said: "The improvements we are making to our timetable from December will deliver even more benefits for our customers, delivering more seats, more services, and a new station in the north east of Glasgow."The pound million investment in new and upgraded trains and the infrastructure improvements across the country are all part of building the best railway Scotland has ever had."

title: stobo-raises-2-700-charity-cocktail-sales
story: THIRSTY guests at Stobo did their bit for charity last month ndash just through drinking cocktails.The Peeblesshire venue decided to donate all proceeds from its new drink Pink Rhapsody to the Borders Macmillan Centre.And a total of pound, was raised.Mandy Winyard, director of Stobo Castle: "When the idea was suggested by members of the team, we were more than happy to agree and help a charity close to all our hearts."I would like to thank every one of our loyal guests who purchased a Pink Rhapsody last month, helping to reach this amazing total."A cheque was presented to the charity at Stobo earlier this week,Lynda Taylor, Macmillan nurse consultant and lead clinician in cancer, said: "We want to extend our sincere thanks to the staff at Stobo Castle and, of course, their guests who have helped raise such a fantastic amount of money to help local cancer services here at the Borders General Hospital."We really do appreciate every penny."Donations like these help us do things we wouldnrsquot be able to with our core budget and its these little extras and enhancements that really can make the world of dference to people who are receiving cancer treatment."

title: sevens-event-effectively-closing-off-melrose
story: COMMUNITY leaders have hit out at plans to shut Melrose High Street over Easter weekend.A stretch near the Greenyards will be closed all day during the Saturday and Sunday for the annual sevens tournament.There will also be a two-week closure on St Maryrsquos Road, where a stand will be erected for the event.And traders are worried it will affect footfall at one of their busiest times of the year.Martin Baird, who is a butcher in the town, told the recent meeting of Melrose Community Council: ldquoI am in favour of holding the sevens tournament, it is just a shame that the High Street will be closed over Easter Weekend. This High Street needs all the help it can get.Community councillor Graham Barker agreed, adding: ldquoThese are quite y road closures.ldquoClosing off the High Street is effectively closing off the town.For the first time, the annual tournament will be run over four days.At last Wednesdayrsquos meeting, concerns were also raised about people getting access to the Parish Church on Easter Sunday.But bosses at the local club say they are doing their best to minimise disruption.Alan Wilkinson, operations manager at Melrose Rugby, said: ldquoWe havenrsquot considered parking at the Parish Church yet, but we will take that away and come up with a plan.ldquoThere are lots of discussions to be had with the council and safety must come first.ldquoThe High Street will be closed in the usual place, but this year it will be closed from Saturday morning until Sunday evening.ldquoHowever residents will still be able to get access.A packed programme of events is being planned.And it will all kick off on Thursday, April , with the lsquoA Question of Rugbyrsquo quiz.An under s competition will take place on the Friday and a nightclub will be set up in a marquee in Gibson Park.The senior matches will be held over the Saturday and Sunday and the competition will finish with a concert. Mr Wilkinson said: ldquoIt will be an ambitious four-day event this year, because our ultimate aim is to attract the World Rugby Sevens in .ldquoWe are expecting , to , people on the Saturday and up to , for the nightclub event.ldquoWe also think there will be around , people at the concert on the Sunday.ldquoThe concert will be finished in time for people to get the last train from Tweedbank.ldquoHowever, we are hoping people will stay in the town longer when they come here. That will help local businesses.

title: online-self-help-guide-asksara-launches-borders
story: A FREE, online self-help guide has been launched by the Health and Social Care Partnership to help people find products and solutions which enable people to stay at home for longer.AskSARA is an online resource to help people live le to the highest standard by improving their quality of le by making skills such as cooking, bathing and taking medication, easier.This can be provided through mobility equipment or products which encourage independence.AskSARA is a  hour service and is open to family members, carers and friends, as well as service users.In partnership with the Disabled Living Foundation to provide the Borders AskSARA programme, the first of its kind in Scotland.To use the service, people have to choose between three options - health, home or daily activities - and answer some questions to receive a report from an occupational therapist who will offer recommendations for advice and support.If any concerns are raised in the report, AskSARA will suggest an occupational therapy session through a What Matters Hub.Developers say that AskSARA has the capability to improve capacity in the community for those who access health and social care services to better manage their conditions and support those who care for them.AskSARA also have the opportunity to improve the overall health of the population and reduce the number of hospital admissions.Councillor Tom Weatherston, Executive Member for Adult Social Care, said: ldquoPeople are increasingly willing and able to exert more choice and control over the things that will make a dference to their lives but with so much information available online, it can be dficult to know what can be trusted."AskSARA is an award-winning, tested resource that provides expert advice and information on products and equipment that can help you, or someone you care about, with your health, your home or your daily activities.ldquoWith access to over , daily living products from more almost , trusted suppliers, it has the potential to be of signicant help to people and I would encourage anyone who thinks they may benefit to go through the self-assessment process and take advantage of the personalised guidance that AskSARA provides.ldquoWe also hope that carers will find AskSARA useful by helping to identy suitable equipment for the people they care for. If they are looking for support for themselves in their caring role, there is a wide range of information and advice available from the Borders Carers Centre and they shouldnrsquot hesitate to contact them.To access AskSARA, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk asksaraFor any queries regarding an AskSARA report or for more information, visit your local What Matters Hub, which can be found via www.scotborders.gov.uk whatmattershubs or call the Customer Advice and Support Services line on   .

title: lacklustre-november-retailers-shoppers-held-spending-black-friday
story: High street retailers suffered a lacklustre November in the critical build-up to Christmas as shoppers held off on spending ahead of Black Friday, figures show.In-store sales declined by .% year-on-year in November from an already negative base of minus .%, according to BDOrsquos High Street Sales Tracker .Figures across the month suggest that discounting has become increasingly important for driving consumer spending, with retailers experiencing a lacklustre month before a substantial increase in sales the week of Black Friday.Black Friday fell a week later this year, distorting year-on-year figures, but BDO said in-store like-for-like sales were down .% on the same week last year ndash one of the worst weekly results since the ldquoBeast from the East hit Britain last March.However, the week of Black Friday provided retailers with a much-needed boost, with in-store and non-store sales soaring by % and % respectively.Sophie Michael, head of retail and wholesale at BDO, said: ldquoThe figures for November are dficult to interpret as a late Black Friday means year-on-year comparisons are not straightforward.ldquoIf we adjust for the impact of Black Friday in , the overall results for November were more respectable with in-store sales jumping by approximately % and non-store sales climbing by around % year-on-year.ldquoWhat is abundantly clear, however, is just how important the promotional event and heavy discounting have become to the high street. Shoppers simply werenrsquot willing to part with their pounds until hefty price cuts took place, as the steep decline the week before Black Friday illustrates.She added: ldquoGiven the poor performance of UK retail for the year and the distressing dependence on steep discounting, retailers will be desperately hoping that this December wonrsquot prove, yet again, to be another disastrous month of Christmas trading..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Lacklustre November for retailers as shoppers held spending until Black Friday

title: delight-bronx-boxing-club-club-finds-new-home
story: Members of the Bronx Boxing Gym, formerly of Tranent, will share space at  Musselburgh High Street with mixed martial arts school Forza MMA, run by Italian-born Vincenzo Parente, who was brought up in Leith but is originally from Naples.Mr Parente said there was a lot of ldquohype and excitement locally about the new facility, which will be called the Fit-in Fitness Gym, featuring dferent training sections, a coffee shop and chill-out zone.He has a -year lease on former Co-op premises on High Street, which has been closed for  years, and offered space to the Bronx Boxing Gym, which was on the lookout for a new, permanent home.Internal work is being carried out to enable the boxers and martial arts members to work in tandem in separate parts of the available space.John McCallum, from Haddington, one of the Bronx Boxing Gymrsquos four volunteer coaches, said the gym was lucky to have secured the new premises after having to vacate its base at the former Tranent Methodist Church which became unsafe and needed substantial repairs.The boxing club is already in place at its new home, with the mixed martial arts gym due to follow suit at the start of next year.Mr McCallum, who has his own roofing company, said: ldquoIt has worked out perfectly for us.ldquoThe Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent was about  square metres ndash this is about  square metres. We were always looking for that space because we needed to put a ring in.The boxing club, which has a number of Scottish champions amongst its members, both male and female, trains on a Monday and Wednesday, -.pm, and a Friday, -.pm.Trips to New York to compete and train have been undertaken by the club, which has members from East Lothian, Midlothian and as far afield as Berwick.Anyone interested in finding out more or joining the boxing club should go along to any of the training sessions or contact the coaches via Facebook.ldquoNo one is turned away, said Mr McCallum.The other coaches ndash Tommy Quinn, who lives in Port Seton Richard Snaith, from Dunbar and Marc Skinner, a Tranent resident ndash are on hand to put boxers through their paces each week.ldquoWe are also very lucky we have good members of the committee and good parents who support the club, said Mr McCallum, whose son John is also a boxer.

title: cockenzie-family-return-italian-roots-open-food-lovers-paradise
story: They have restored the home of their ancestors in Picinisco in Lazio, Italy, and turned it into a holiday destination complete with a boutique hotel, cookery school and winery.Members of the Di Ciacca family moved to Cockenzie  years ago and Cesido Di Ciacca took over The Cockenzie Cafe, a cafe, fish  chip shop and ice-cream shop, in .The family lived above the shop on  High Street and integrated themselves into the community. Cesido was soon the honorary president of Cockenzie Star football club.The shop stayed in the family and closed in , just before Cesidorsquos son, Johnnie Di Ciacca, died.Johnniersquos own son, who is now  and is also called Cesido, lived in Cockenzie from his birth until he married his we Selina, , in . The couple continued to live in Scotland until  when they started their new business venture in Italy.The last of the Di Ciacca family to live in Picinisco died in  and their hamlet lsquoI Ciaccarsquo had been abandoned ever since.I Ciacca is a small hamlet near the town of Picinisco, Val Comino. The area is a historic region between Rome and Naples.I Ciacca has now been established as an lsquoAlbergo Dfusorsquo, which translates as a lsquoscattered hotelrsquo.Cesido and Selina moved to I Ciacca and began restoring the buildings ahead of opening their boutique hotel, Sotto Le Stelle, in .The same year, the Di Ciacca family started to clear the ground to plant vines at I Ciacca. A vineyard has now been re-cultivated and local farm produce revitalised, enabling the family to bring food, drink and authentic Italian hospitality back to Picinisco.The historic family buildings have also now been restored and turned into the cookery school, winery and further accommodation.This second and final phase of the I Ciacca project was completed in September this year. The hotel, cookery school and winery are now complete and taking bookings for overnight stays, cookery classes and winery vineyard tours.Cesidio Di Ciacca, said: ldquoOne hundred years since leaving to come to Scotland, wersquore immensely proud to be putting Picinisco, Val di Comino, back on the food loversrsquo map with the launch of I Ciacca.ldquoI Ciacca was home to generations of the Di Ciacca family for over  years. By breathing new le into our familyrsquos forgotten hamlet and the town, wersquore now able to offer a new generation of food and wine enthusiasts the chance to experience authentic Italian hospitality in an area of outstanding natural beauty.ldquoOur familyrsquos heritage of quality ice cream, food and hospitality since  in East Lothian is still to be found in Scotland today, including some of the best restaurants, cafes, delicatessens and wine merchants in Edinburgh.ldquoFrom I Ciacca we organise food and wine tours to learn about genuine local foods from pasta, pizza, cheese, prosciutto and other cured meats, to our own olive oil and letrsquos not forget wine ndash especially our very special Maturano.The Di Ciacca family is also working with one of the worldrsquos top winemakers, Alberto Antonini, to produce a new range of speciality organic wines made from their own Maturano grapes ndash a unique iety from Picinisco, almost lost and only recently brought back into commercial cultivation.The Di Ciacca family has just released its Nostalgia IGT Lazio Maturano in Scotland, which is the first time that Maturano wine will be commercially available in the country. It is now available to purchase from Edinburghrsquos Valvona  Crolla.Cesido, his we Selina, and son Giovanni, , now live in Picinisco for most of the year, but still spend time in Scotland. His daughter Sofia, , lives between Edinburgh and Picinisco.Cesidorsquos brother Paul and his cousins Marietta and Laura still live in Cockenzie whilst his sisters are Mary Contini, director of Valvona and Crolla Ltd in Edinburgh, and Carina Contini of Contini George Street, Cannonball Restaurant  Bar, and The Scottish Cafe  Restaurant at the Scottish National Gallery in Edinburgh.

title: plans-transport-hub-including-car-park-haddington
story: Following a series of closed door meetings, proposals by East Lothian Council for land next to Whittingehame Drive will be revealed to the public at a drop-in meeting in Haddington Town House on December , -pm.A proposal of applicationnotice for the site, which surrounds the townrsquos skate park and all-weather G sports pitches, was validated by the local authorityrsquos planning department last Wednesday.The simple drawings, which do not give any specic detail, show an area of land stretching from almost the gates at Haddington Golf Club in the south to the River Tyne in the north. The site borders the golf course and St Martinrsquos Cemetery.A formal planning application, which should set out exactly what is planned, is yet to be submitted.The local authority says it wants to create a ldquotransport hub with associated parking spaces and ldquobus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways.If approved, this would, says the council, have ldquothe potential to free up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services and tourist attractions.Work on the project,approved, could begin as early as April next year. The car park would have somewhere between  and  spaces, the Courier has learnt.But some community figures in Haddington have accused the council of keeping people in the dark over the project.Liz McDougall, chairwoman of the Nungate Gala, said: ldquoMy thoughts are it is such a bad move.ldquoIt is going to endanger kidsrsquo lives and I cannot see the relevance in putting the car park down there.ldquoThey would be much better putting it on the other side of the town where they are throwing up houses and a school [at Letham Mains].Mrs McDougall questioned why the early plans had been made public last Wednesday ndash the day after the townrsquos community council meeting ndash when they were listed as being published the day beforehand on the local authorityrsquos planning site.She encouraged as many members of the public as possible to go to the drop-in meeting.Mrs McDougall said: ldquoI will do everything in my power andthat means trawling through the Nungate to get people to sign a petition against it I will."This should not be done.Pat Lemmon, from the townrsquos community council, felt there were a number of questions yet to be answered.She said: ldquoI find it very hard that the plans came in the day after the community council meeting. The timing was bad.The Whittingehame Drive plans come as early-stage proposals have been mooted for a complete revamp of parking in the centre of Haddington, which, as previously reported by the Courier, could see the long-stay car park at the townrsquos Tesco be made short-stay and the loss of up to  parking spaces on High Street and Market Street, a prospect which has concerned some town traders.The Courier submitted a number of written questions to East Lothian Council about the transport hub plans, including whether there would be a charge to use the car park and shuttle buses to the town centre what the projectrsquos cost would be and how it would be funded.The council responded that ldquowork on developing the proposals is still ongoing, adding: ldquoWe will set out more detailed plans in the months ahead, when such information is available.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe local community in Haddington first put forward their ideas in their lsquoVision for Haddington Town Centrersquo back in  and East Lothian Council has been supporting them in delivering their aims which includes lsquoimproving the attractiveness, ality and accessibility of the town in support of the community and local businessesrsquo.ldquoWorking closely with local groups, East Lothian Councilrsquos priorities are to protect and enhance the local environment while supporting the local economy, including town centre retailers and other businesses."The plans are ambitious and seek to create a transport hub with associated parking spaces that addresses climate change through the inclusion of EV chargepoints, bus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways."This has the potential to free-up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services, and tourist attractions during the day."To help develop these proposals the council has secured signicant funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Town Centre Fund and has also made an application to the European Regional Development Fund.ldquoA public exhibition, where initial plans can be viewed, is expected to be held before Christmas."Comments received will help to form a full planning application and so itrsquos too early to provide further details at this stage but East Lothian Council remains committed to continuing our engagement with local stakeholders on this initiative and setting out more detailed plans in the months ahead.
